clinical_study.brief_title: Endoscopic Ultrasound and Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography for Malignant Distal Biliary Obstruction
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Trial Comparing Endoscopic Ultrasound-guided Biliary Drainage (EUS-BD) and Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for Malignant Distal Biliary Obstruction

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the need to use mechanical lithotripsy between patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS for removal of difficult bile duct stones

detailed_description.textblock: Gallstones can cause pain, jaundice or pancreatitis by blocking the bile duct. Bile duct stones should be removed during an endoscopic procedure called endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) using basket or balloons. However, large stones (more than 15mm in size) or multiple stones can be difficult to remove during ERCP with routine techniques. In such cases, we have to break up the stone into small pieces before it can be removed safely. We call this mechanical lithotripsy. Mechanical lithotripsy can be done by the use of a basket and a sheath that can be wrapped around the stone, which are in turn attached to a handle that is turned to result in stone breakage. But, this technique is difficult to perform. Other easier standard-of-care techniques used to remove difficult bile duct stones during an ERCP are peroral cholangioscopy-directed laser lithotripsy (POC-LL) and endoscopic balloon sphincterotomy (EBS). The POC-LL technique helps us to directly see the bile duct stone. Using this technique a catheter is inserted into the endoscope and into the bile duct to reach the stone. Using this catheter, the energy from laser (laser lithotripsy) can be accurately focused onto the stone to cause stone break-up. After the stone is broken to small pieces it can be removed by usual methods such as use of a balloon or a basket. EBS is a technique in which an 8 to 20mm balloon is used to enlarge (dilation) the opening of the bile duct. Following dilation, the stone is removed using routine methods. It is at the discretion of the treating physician on which technique he will use to remove the bile duct stone. The purpose of this study is to compare the need to use mechanical lithotripsy between patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS for removal of difficult bile duct stones

primary_outcome.measure: Peroral Cholangioscopy-guided Laser Lithotripsy versus Endoscopic Balloon Sphincteroplasty
primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoint of the study is the proportion of patients requiring the use of the mechanical lithotripter or endoscopic ballon for bile duct stone removal during index ERCP.

secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of between patients complete bile duct stone clearance at index ERCP undergoing POC-LL and EBS.
Comparison of procedure duration (mins) for patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS
Comparison of total number of ERCP sessions performed for complete stone clearance procedure of patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS.
Comparison of adverse event rates during and after the procedure of patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS.
Comparison of duration of hospital stay of patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS.
Comparison of total hospital costs (in US dollars) incurred by patients undergoing POC-LL and EBS.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. All patients referred to the Florida Hospital Center for Interventional Endoscopy for removal of suspected bile duct stones, with subsequent failure of stone removal using endoscopic sphincterotomy and standard accessories only.
2. All patients referred to the Florida Hospital Center for Interventional Endoscopy following previous failed attempts at bile duct stone removal
3. Age ≥ 18 years
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Age <18 years
2. Suspected/confirmed pancreaticobiliary malignancy
3. Unable to safely undergo ERCP for any reason
4. Coagulopathy (INR >1.6, Thrombocytopenia with platelet count <50,000/ml)
5. Altered surgical anatomy (Billroth II/Roux-en-Y, gastric bypass)
6. Unable to provide consent for any reason
7. Any female with a positive pregnancy test
